First time I disagree that much on facts.
There is pretty much of "Geneva convention" about love, it's just as dysfunctional as Geneva convention on war

First - there are obviously rules on consent - from age, to chemical situation in the brain to financial-administrative obstacles of romance
Second - there are rules for long-term relations - in many countries they are counted as marriage to prevent some kind of dead end
Third - there are some rules against cheating, at least in marriage it may give disadvantage on divorce
Fourth - many "weapons" common in more barbaric times are prohibited much harder for the case of love, ie stalking is often a crime or taboo for love matters while same actions for business reasons nearly never get prosecuted

so here's the actual thing about superluminal travel. Nothing about relativity or any of the laws or theories that arose from it prohibit faster than light travel. What the do prohibit, is accelerating to the speed of light from lower than speed of light motion. It would take both an infinite amount of time, and and infinite amount of energy to reach the speed of light as a particle with mass. However, faster than light travel is not prohibited, and if something travels faster than flight (we can't but certain theoretical particles might) some weird things happen. For instance, particles traveling faster than light would go back in time.

As opposed to the prefix hetero-, meaning "the different" or "the other".

I would feel no empathy for the enemy because they are killing my soldiers, and I am killing theirs. They should feel no empathy for me, but yet so many countries agreed to the Geneva conventions. The Geneva conventions are actually pertaining to the treatment of wounded combatants, Prisoners of War and non combatants (civilians). The only convention about anything else was the convention on conventional weapons, which outlined the use and prohibition of certain munitions. Espionage isn't covered, as they are not considered combatants nor non combatants. As such, they are exempt from the Geneva Conventions, and hence have a history of being shot on site.
The Hague conventions outline the rules of what is acceptable in battle.
Together, the Geneva and Hague conventions outline the rules of combat, and comprise the basis for what is known as the Law of Armed Conflict.

I was listening to this while taking a hot bath and was pondering the topic alongside of your own explanations, Michael. You made a very good argument that not all is fair in war, however it kind of is in love. We can legislate our actions but we can not legislate how we feel.

This had me thinking if the use of the word "War" in the phrase itself is a form of self obfuscation. A lie we tell ourselves. I would then argue that what we really mean by "War" in "All is fair in love and war"; would be "Hate". Hate is as much of a human emotional condition as the feeling of love. It's simply something that on a very primal base level we can not control.

Finally I would say that by rephrasing it to be "All is fair in love and hate" would be more accurate. Primarily because when we love someone or something we will do anything and break whatever rules we can do be with them. Whereas with hate we will do whatever it takes to avoid or eliminate something. I would suggest the primary motive is the willingness of a person to break the rules they know they should abide by.

To say all is fair in love is as foolish as saying all is Fair in War in this human society.

Love itself is not an emotion, nor is it a condition, it is the proof of human moral fiber and social culture. infatuation is a condition, lust is a temptation, happiness and to some extent Satisfaction it can be argued; are our emotions. but love is not a noun in and of itself. It is a verb. Love itself in action, passively or otherwise, is a choice.

That is to say, anyone can claim to be in love but to have a truthful example of love is almost impossible in all the ways it has been portrayed as a reaction or chemical process. Let's then discuss Occam's razor in this. To say that love is an indefinable trait of life means that no one could ever describe even in allegory what it was, yet we have social constructs directly built around love, its purpose, weaknesses, and strengths as the said social construct. We understand it's base origins and needs to exist. Therefore it is not an ephemeral and abstract idea.

With all of this in mind Love as a reaction is dismissive of the codependent nature of love. That it is something to simply disappear over time meaning it was never meant to be, to begin with, yet it is stated that Love is never wrong...A paradox if love is defined as a simple reactive process meant to attach people emotionally, and spiritually to the point of physical intimacy to produce children.

Thusly Love as a reaction, is impossible.

Chemical processes themselves are an unreliable answer to this query as the brain itself can relay the decoded input from singular or repeated encounters with someone who releases the perfect mixture of pheromones behavior and social persona to create output in reaction. Yet, we've already seen that love as a reaction is not a process that reaches the purpose of love.

At this stage, this argument against a chemical reaction would dive deep into the true presence of the brain as the core of who you are as a living breathing person. Nevertheless, that digression would be too absolute to worry ourselves with at this moment. Let us postpone that argument to simply discuss the true nature of love as a part of life, experiencing it and it's development as a behavior.

Thus, if love as a simple reaction to stimuli, and furthermore relegating love to simply a chemical reaction refutes the true purpose and birth of love, thus it makes far too many assumptions to be a viable explanation of love.

In this regard, the simplest and most complete explanation of Love as an aspect of life. More explicitly Human life, as a very specific moral, social, curious and self-actualizing creature. Love is a decision to become codependent with another being whom you hold or wish to hold in close regard.

Now, that may sound cold and mechanical in the favor of love, but that is the point of this discussion. The mechanics of love. Not the explicit practice of it. That too is simply far too complex to discuss.

Love itself is a choice, as proof simply in the argument, For love being a reaction. that it fades after time unless the connection is absolutely self-sufficient. That is to say, the bond does not require any attempts to adjust and course-correct the perceived person value of each action taken in the relationship. This in and of itself is foolish. As codependent or Symbiotic life forms require communication and consensus to survive.

With the purpose of survival, when it comes to life as we know it, being to reproduce and allow our genetic material to continue. Love is a higher moral plane of relating to a mate and a symbiote, that is to say, like any other need for sentient life to survive, much less thrive, There must be conscious decision and purpose in relating to another being that is going to trust in being symbiotic to you.

Thus, all being fair in love is nothing more than the foolish desire to e self-righteous in a society that values being known as correct above actually being truthful.

War. War never changes.
Since the dawn of humankind, when our ancestors first discovered the killing power of rock and bone, blood has been spilled in the name of everything: from God to justice to simple, psychotic rage.

In the year 2077, after millennia of armed conflict, the destructive nature of man could sustain itself no longer. The world was plunged into an abyss of nuclear fire and radiation.

But it was not, as some had predicted, the end of the world. Instead, the apocalypse was simply the prologue to another bloody chapter of human history. For man had succeeded in destroying the world - but war, war never changes.

In the early days, thousands were spared the horrors of the holocaust by taking refuge in enormous underground shelters, known as vaults. But when they emerged, they had only the hell of the wastes to greet them - all except those in Vault 101. For on that fateful day, when fire rained from the sky, the giant steel door of Vault 101 slid closed... and never reopened. It was here you were born. It is here you will die.

Somehow I disagree with almost everything in this video. Love is not opposed to war, like he says, with war being created by humans and love not created by humans. Love is opposed to hatred, and none of the two are created by humans, and from both of these, some things created by humans follow. They are very similar in this sense. And saying that there is the Geneva convention for war, and that there is no equivalent for love is a bit far fetched. Geneva convention does not even forbid to kill people. Are you allowed to kill someone in a relationship ? Geneva convention forbids to use landmines and fragmentation bombs, this is a totally other level. Yes, in love, the law does not forbid you to try to seduce another woman when you are in a relationship, but you cannot compare this to the use of landmines that rip peoples legs off. You cannot argue that we have no obligation in morality in love relationships but we do in war. The law even forbids you to slap people, when Geneva convention does not even forbid you to kill them. It just argues about the way you do it.
And no, I don't think being faithful to the person I love is a barrier that I create for myself because of moral values. I don't do it because it is something that the person I love really wouldn't want, and it would hurt her. And loving someone precisely mean wanting that person to be happy. So it is not that I want to cheat on her but force myself not to, the thing is I simply DO NOT want to cheat on her. This all stems from the idea that our true nature is to be "sinners", that we are all basically selfish people and we need moral laws to prevent us from doing all those things that we would really like to do deep down. Our true nature is to be good and to not want to hurt people. We do hurt people sometimes, not because of our true nature, but precisely because we are drawn away from our true nature because of confusion. Actually, the biggest reason why we do hurt people the most is BECAUSE we think our true nature is to be sinners and that others are too.

Interesting video.  It's funny to me how humanity's idea of love has changed over time and how it varies among societies.  For instance, we don't legislate love yet when it comes to certain people loving certain things, we do.  Homosexuality, pedophilia, etc.  Love IS a condition, unavoidable, yet in certain cases we question people's motives, as if love was a means to some other nefarious end.  And in some cases, it seems so undeniable, as in pedophilia.  Those people are obviously sick and twisted.  Just like if someone were to drop a bowling ball on someone's head and claim, "hey, I can't stop gravity!"  I mean in a sense they're correct, but it was the way they manipulated gravity to their own ends that is the problem.  And there are even those cases throughout history of people being told to love this or that person, or that they simply can't love this or that person. "The final two [committing perfidy in a time of war, or cheating on your significant other] ... are voluntary obstacles, reflecting what we value... We didn't get to create protons or planets, they were already here, but we do get to create judgements."

Do we?

It would seem that these "obstacles" were already here before us as well, and our values reflect them, not the other way around. Why else would we hold ourselves to them? If we created these obstacles or "rules of conduct", then we are above them, and we can alter or dispose of them as we chose. If we created these "rules of conduct", they are of less worth than the dirt we came from -- and that includes trust, loyalty, and not murdering people because they get in your way.

Most people instinctively feel a strong revulsion toward that concept. It's that revulsion which would indicate these "rules of conduct" or "obstacles" existed before us as well, and are therefore before and above us. Someone or Something put these non-physical "laws" in place before we were ever here. And we agree to most of them (trust, loyalty, not murdering people), validating that Someone or Something as not only good but also as greater that we are. So the next logical question -- what else does that Someone or Something have to say about the universe we live in?

I can't agree that love is an inevitable condition. Love is a choice. I think that probably the wrongest idea entertainment passes on to us is that love is more of a feeling than actions. To love and to feel passion isn't the same. Loving is a verb, therefore an action. There aren't verbs such as happing or sading or nervousing. Those are feelings or emotions. But there is the verb "to love". Love IS actions, thoughts and intentions. Expecting to FEEL love all of the time is the reason why people don't stay together as a couple. Demanding to feel passionate is stupid and egoistical while loving would be more like trying to make the other person feel good WETHER OR NOT you feel good yourself. The trick for long-lasting relationships? Giving up on finding the person that will make you happy but becoming the person that makes the other happy instead. Now, you should never demand it, but if you're lucky, it may be that the other person learns it with you or simply feels like giving something back. Anyway, I don't think love should be seen as a condition but rather as a choice. I also think everything is fair in love. The thing is that the moment you decide to do something for your own interest and for the other person's detriment, it's simply not love!

I would argue that things like laws of war are followed less out of honor than practicality. The big thing about most of the rules in the Geneva conventions is that they are not actually particularly practical, at least more than once. Killing medics ensures that wounded soldiers fight to the last breath rather than going home to drain the enemy economy for months at least, and refusing quarter means that enemy soldiers will never see reason to surrender even if massively outmatched in every way. At the same time, breaking laws like the Geneva conventions provokes outrage that might turn public sentiment against the war for your own civilians, may weaken morale, and will often cause allies to back off while giving enemies an excuse to side against you.
Similarly, in love you are restricted by the knowledge that if you do something sufficiently dishonorable you run the risk of a subject of affection finding out and refusing you, leaving such an action worse than pointless in many cases.

The big thing that keeps bugging me with the "rules of war" is what happens if you face someone who refuses to follow them. Normally, I wouldn't mind following the rules, because both sides are following them, but if one side doesn't just ignore them, but shows contempt for them, if and when victory is actively on the line, should we not throw off these artificial limits? Now, I'm not in favor of casually disregarding the rules of war, nor am I in favor of disregarding them against a power which does abide by those rules. But I am not in favor of sacrificing victory against a power who does disregard these rules. Let's take ISIS as an example, if they hide behind civilians, or in a hospital, or dare I say it, a mosque, While otherwise, I would prefer not to violate the rules, I would have no problem breaking the rules when they essentially don't apply, because the opponent is blatantly breaking them as well. If there were consequences for that action after I win, then I would argue my case, but would not dodge responsibility.

While some of the 'Rules of War' are extremely reasonable, many of them are nothing more than a bunch of people who have invested trillions of dollars into development of ballistic weaponry trying to prevent other people from using more effective weapons. Idiocracy was a documentary, not a comedy. Everything depicted in it is real. It has long since been established that fertility rates are negatively correlated with intelligence and education level, meaning the dumber you are the more kids you have. Meanwhile, academics have fewer kids. Back in the day (pre-industrialism), this wasn't a problem. Because back then, negative Natural Selection was still hard at work killing off the shallow end of the gene pool. Dumber people were more likely to die simply on account of being dumb, since they would do stupid shit like try to wrestle a bear or climb a really high building with no safety equipment to impress their equally dumb friends/potential sexual partners. Their numbers were kept in check by their stupidity. Also, since they were generally poorer and there was no social safety net, they were the first to go in times of famine and disease epidemics. All of this is known as negative selection. Basically all of the factors that combine to kill you off before you can spread your defective genes. Positive selection is the opposite, it is all the traits and characteristics a person possesses that increase their chance of survival and passing on their genes, like intelligence, for instance. Intelligent people were more successful and wealthy, and therefore more likely to survive famines and disease outbreaks since they could afford the higher priced food and could retreat to their country homes in case of epidemics in the high density cities. This lead to average IQ going up through all of human history, since evolution positively selected intelligence, and negatively selected stupidity. But thanks to modern social safety nets, everybody gets taken care of and is protected from their own stupidity. If some idiot decides to juggle chainsaws to impress his gutter trash girlfriend and ends up losing a few limbs, society will expend much wealth and effort to patch him up and ensure he survives to pass on his defective genes. We have effectively disrupted the Natural Order of things. We have more or less eliminated negative selection for everybody, allowing everyone to procreate, no matter how useless they are. Even the lowest, dumbest, most useless and worthless gutter trash can grow up to spawn tens of worthless offspring these days. Famine and disease cannot touch them, since modern medicine and welfare benefits ensure nobody needs to starve or die of sickness. This isn't how it's supposed to be. And the effects of all this are starting to be felt. Throughout the 1900's, average IQ's have gone up due to the flynn effect, which is the increase in IQ due to education and good nutrition during adolescence. This is separate from innate IQ, which is the IQ you are born with and which cannot be changed by education. Everyone has a base level of IQ that they are born with, and then the flynn effect IQ gets added to it through education and good nutrition. But those can only add so many IQ points. Eventually, you reach a ceiling, beyond which IQ cannot increase. The higher the innate base IQ is, the higher the ceiling will be. but base IQ has actually gone down since the 1800's. the only reason average IQ's went up is due to education. but now we are reaching the limits of what education can do. the useless half-wits are outbreeding the non-useless segment of the population, and pulling average innate IQ's down. The only way to reverse this trend is to somehow lower their fertility rate. now, i'm no social darwinist or nazi or anything. i certainly don't think we should kill them, but we definitely need some sort of license for having kids. If your IQ is lower than a certain percentile, you don't get to reproduce, period. If you reproduce anyway, you the child will be forcibly aborted, and the people responsible thrown in prison. Or we could just remove all the warning labels from all the bottles of bleach and watch in delight as the idiots start drinking it and dropping like flies.

Fairness in war? Please. In war, you do what is necessary to win. Torture isn't required for that and it is actually counter productive. The victim will tell you what he thinks you want to hear. Sodium Pentothal or Sodium Amatol is a much better solution and is likely to get better results. As for the weather, why not weaponize it?

Also, bombing a school is a valid tactic although it's preferable to do it when class is not in session. A school is a propaganda machine and therefore is fair game. Bombing a hospital is not a viable tactic but not out of any humanitarian concern. A hospital is a resource drain. It takes resources away from he enemy's war effort.

The bottom line is this. War is not nice, neat and pretty. It is an ugly, barbaric business that calls for barbarity. Which is why it should be avoided at all reasonable costs.

I completely disagree. The marriage contract can be concidered the "rules of love". While traditionally the concept of marriage was not tied to the notion of romantic love the idea that couples in a relationship have certain duties and obligation and prohibition was clearly established, even if the motive was not emotional protection or fostering of romantic dealings. Almost universally the idea of infidelity is seen as a negative destructive force in both romantic and platonic relationships. And infidelity and adultery was one of the earliest codified reasons to legally dissolve a marriage. In the last 100 years as the idea of romantic love was melded with the institution of marriage we began to see that emotional and physical abuse are now considered illegal behavior and also grounds to legally dissolve a marriage. The point is that like the Geneva convention the idea of "fair" love has also been explored and imposed.

If you look at the Genevra Convention it isn't really about keeping war fair. It is about not causing unnecessary suffering. It provides a guide for the proper treatment of POWs, treatment of non-combatant civilians (Those civilians not involved in making the war possible) and weapons that should not be used. For example chemical or biological weapons are banned while weapons designed to set live enemy troops on fire are not. Chemical and biological weapons are too persistent indiscriminate and take too long to be effective, while weapons like napalm are considered necessary even though it causes significant suffering.

I think your comparison on love and war is intriguing, but upon consideration, I'm going to disagree.  Isn't the "free for all" on love a more modern idea?  We used to "legally" punish for adultery; we socially shame those who betray their spouses today, and prenups are many times considered invalid if a spouse cheats.  Women can be stoned in other countries for infidelity.  Divorce has become more socially acceptable but that's also recent, and same-sex marriage is still controversial in many places in the US, and illegal in other countries.  So if love is considered a condition that other people can empathize with, then wouldn't these rules and/or shaming not exist?

In short, we cannot put laws into love to keep it fair because we have no control in it. People will fall in and out of love involuntarily, whether we wish to or not. There's not much we can do to limit how we may feel. In vise versa, war is just an action that we can decide to take and therefore be able to fence.

You can be attracted and even fall in love with many people, but in my definition, only love the person you love. Love is a state of mind and matter of will. You WANT to love somebody year after year. Even if you're attracted to other people, you don't cheat because you love and you want to love the person you're with. Many people, unfortunately, don't have the spine and self-discipline to be faithful over the years. For me, love is a lot less magical than commonly is considered, but more stable. It's about you and your choices.

It's interesting how this video points out a discontinuity in humanity with regard to love. This has existed for some time, but I never thought of it in these terms. We let our emotions of anger, pride and even hate lead us to war, but we have no problem putting in rules to mitigate those emotions. But we will follow the emotions of love almost blindly. "Follow your heart" the common expression goes, but we don't usually mean "to war" when we say it.

But it wasn't always this way, there used to be more social laws to govern who and how we loved. I think to times and cultures with match makers, dowries and traditions. Not that these were right all the time, and not that we have to bring them back, but it begs the question: why do we have a problem with rules in one area of emotion, and not have a problem with rules in another?

The only war to which there abides no "laws", implicit or otherwise, is civil war, or war between different social groups. During the French revolution, for example, there could be no "laws" to which the revolutionaries abide by - they are in the processes of destroying an old order and a previous substrate from which laws were derived. The only law was the protection of the revolution by any means. Wars between nations, conversely, are fought for the fulfillment of interests (of capital) by any means. Which is why this is fucking stupid: War DOES have implicit rules, as those who go to war are not exercising the epitome of conflict, but fulfilling certain productive needs. During wars between Hellenistic states, for example, they possessed the same mode(s) of production and social foundations, these societies weren't really that different: The implicit rules of war were simple, that they abide by a certain constraint of production. The reason why there was an actual threat of total extinction during the cold war was because the Soviet Union and the United States were axiomatically different and represented a different order. Because war is an extension of politics, today nuclear war is (while possible) less likely - those responsible for war have definitive interests which don't include extinction. During the cold war, conversely, those in power were willing to risk everything, as the enemy meant the undoing of the system from which their rule derived. Look at WWI - was this truly a "conflict" in the true sense? No! All fronts, and all sides were EXACTLY the same. That is not 'war', that is a false conflict. 

Why? Because they are tied to specific interests - war is by nature an extension of politics and NOT the other way around. The only laws of war are the fulfillment the interests of those responsible for war - it's not "human nature", it possesses a real systemic function.

A perfect video as a preface to the fact that love does not exist.

Can you see love?
Can you hear love? 
What is love?

Perhaps we all experience it differently, perhaps we experience nothing. 

Love, unlike other human emotional states (e.g. happiness, fear, anxiety) cannot be tested like the others can. 

I have a strong bond to my genetic relatives - that which we call 'love' or more accurately, 'relative love'. I have a strong bond to a girl I like, we also call that 'love' or more accurately the 'love' most people mean when they speak of it. 

The strong bond between family is genetically preprogrammed for obvious reasons. 

Calling the 'strong bond' between man and woman; 'love' makes no sense, at least from the perspective of being preprogrammed genetically. We pick our partners based on what we as individuals gauge as 'positive' human traits (consciously and/or unconsciously). Yes, once we impregnate a female, we are genetically preprogrammed to care for that female on an unconscious level until our genetic offspring is able to fend for itself. 

But outside of that time period there's no reasonable natural and/or scientific rationale for a monogamous relationship. Yes you might stay life-long monogamous because the partner you found IS the perfect human partner for you and nobody else you meet in life surpasses them, but how often, if at all, does that happen? 

Love is a societal fabrication, or at least a VERY rare occurrence, romanticized (pun very much intended) by the media. Same as the fact girls prefer pink over blue. Reproduce 'smartly' by picking females that you find to be what you interpret as the 'perfect' human and females do the same for the new generation of humans. This ignores the typical rules of today's relationships and encourages couples that would feel they could produce a superior human to do so with great gusto. 

The interesting aspect of the above ramblings of a stoned man is that this is actually some coherent shit. Perhaps men (and women) like me that realise this (in the dawn of near perfect artificial contraception) will become part of the new superior genetic code. Only consciously breeding with females I feel would create a better human.

The "our love and damn the rest" attitude is deplorable, espeically when it is going against a society or family, coursing disruption or pain to others.
I do not see how "Love" should be used as a justification for anything in fact, though literature is against me. Not even "love in marriage" which was afteral, a Victorian ideal created by moralists to further sanctify marriage, that hitherto had only been so in Romantic literary works, as an obligation that spouses must love each other as part of a 'sort of' Devine contract. It is this, coupled with a Millenium of literature that has given us to-day, the idea that marriage is or should be about love, rather than a new stage of love, or necessity in joining families together in times of scarcity as it was in the Middle Ages.

Hmm, many nations accept Geneva conventions as they perceived it gives them some advantage.
See, if soldiers know they will be brutalised and killed if the enemy overwhelmed them then they will fight to the death as literally their lives depend on it. Sun Tzu established that in 500BC that it's beneficial to put an army in a position where they are surrounded and cannot escape, they will focus on fighting. If their enemy gives them a way out, a guarantee of surrender, then they may give up fighting much easier.
It's a similar story with chemical weapons. Chemical weapons don't necessarily give any side any advantage, they spread everywhere and you end up having to take tedious efforts to contain them like gas masks and even full-body suits. It's a whole load of effort to inconvenience everybody.
Best just to agree not to use them.
It's not a matter of fairness, it's cold-rational pragmatism.

As is the case with most laws of war, they are only agreed upon because they think it either has no effect on the outcome of the war or they think they can benefit from it not being there.

First of all, excellent video as always.

But Michael, what if?

What if there was a Geneva Convention for love? Would that be stupid, since nobody would follow these rules anyway, because love, with all its cheating, distrust and envy is such a lawless area, that the created rules would just look ridiculous?

If so, then why do we have something like the Geneva Convention in the first place? It would be just as ridiculous to assume that in a war, every participant would stick to those rules, especially against outlaws like terrorists and anarchists.
No, the Geneva Convention will only be respected as long as the countries see fit, and when it comes to either stick to the rules or losing the war, the Geneva Convention will be broken. And the winner won't be punished for it.
In the end, might makes right, no matter how noble and just the rules of war are.

Back to topic, why is love so glorified? Why do people seem to condone misbehaviour, if conducted in the name of love? Because we just see those emotions as part of our nature? Because men are men and not angels? Because we accepted ourselves as immoral beings, at least in this regard?
But if love is so precious to us, shouldn't we try to protect it with rules? To avoid pain? Or is pain an essential part of the very definition of love?

Abuse in a relationship will be punished, because it hurts people.

Child abuse will be punished, because it hurts people.

But cheating is just Ok, because the heart does what it wants? Doesn't it hurt just as much, even if it is only psychological? More often than not, it is the psychological pain that won't vanish.
I know you can't force people to love each other, but there are wrong and right ways to end things. And what about gold diggers? It doesn't take much to know that faking being in love is perfidious, no matter the cause. Still, there is now law that prohibits such a behaviour.

Please, make a video on judgement, and humanity's ability to judge. Because a human's process of making judgements is so flawed (as you said in the video, love before truth in courts, which is obviously an emotinally ridden incorrect decision) and I would like to know how we as a race can become better at it.

In fact, since we are not able or willing to make wise judgements more often than not, shoudn't we be called Homo sensifer, rather than Homo sapiens?

I think that we must be carefull with the statement that there are no rules in love. No actualy enforceable rules in modern westren society shoud be more accurate. In the early Roman area there was an actual punishment for partners in a maritial Union for not loving your partner. Also in foreign cultures there is still punishment for cheating or divorce. And still here, in our western society there are some rules for love. Social codes still prevent us from being Lawless in matters of love. Our fear of social isolation makes ourselves the gaurians of these codes. Also moral plays a big role in love and is mostly more powerfull than any law ever created by men. Both are not enforceable laws but are most certainly rules we follow or at least try to.
So rational or irrational, fair or not fair there are still rules for love and there has Always been rules for love becouse, I like to believe so, mankind is obcessivly occupied by trying to controle the unpredictable and enforce it in some kind of law.

To anyone curious, there might be a reason Vsauce doesn't upload videos more often. Apart from the tremendous effort and research required to make each video, it is sometimes advantageous to post fewer videos. There was one channel I subscribed to a while ago because I enjoyed their videos, but soon found out they uploaded around 5-10 times daily. It was filling my subscriptions tab faster than I could watch, and as a result, I was not as interested. There is an old saying "absence makes the heart grow fonder". Perhaps the reason you like the videos so much is because you don't get a new one every day. Food for thought.

I don't know what to comment so ill will comment a cookie recipe 

4 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
 2 teaspoons baking soda
 2 cups butter, softened
 1 1/2 cups packed brown sugar
 1/2 cup white sugar
 2 (3.4 ounce) packages instant vanilla pudding mix
 4 eggs
 2 teaspoons vanilla extract
 4 cups semisweet chocolate chips
 2 cups chopped walnuts (optional)
PREP
15 mins
COOK
12 mins
READY IN
1 hr 40 mins Directions
1.Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Sift together the flour and baking soda, set aside.
2.In a large bowl, cream together the butter, brown sugar, and white sugar. Beat in the instant pudding mix until blended. Stir in the eggs and vanilla. Blend in the flour mixture. 3.Finally, stir in the chocolate chips and nuts. Drop cookies by rounded spoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
4.Bake for 10 to 12 minutes in the preheated oven. Edges should be golden brown.﻿

There's no denying that most actions driven by emotional motives are unreasonable (by most standards). Love further amplifies the magnitude of these actions, often rendering them inconceivable by those not under its grasp. Love does not attempt to understand everything, and does not concern itself with logic.

Science on the other hand, has reasonable objectives for most, if not all of its queries. It attempts rationalizes all of its moves, and usually succeeds at doing so. It holds dominion over logic, and logic holds dominion over it. Most people, even those who tend to be more inclined towards other, non-scientific pursuits, can understand its reasoning, motives, goals, and outcomes. The ultimate goal of Science is to gain absolute comprehension and clarity in everything. 

I see this episode as Science attempting to apply its methods to understand the non-reasonable intricacies of Love. In the end, even Science is forced to wordlessly concede to the fact that not all things can be rationalized.﻿

On a grand scale it's easy to understand. If both sides of a war use weapons of mass destruction, humanity is doomed. On a smaller scale, if your enemy starts torturing your soldiers and you do the same, who's won there? They have, they've made you change who you are and abandon your principles, what you're fighting for in the first place.

I see a lot of people saying that the "laws of war" are ineffective or pointless.  And while they may very well be for the most part, I do believe it does serve some purpose.  That is, if the "majority" of countries around the world agree to a set of laws (usually via the UN), then when one country violates them (whether they agreed to the laws or not), it gives the remaining countries a sort of "rallying point" to come together and deal with the violating country in question with the combined force of the majority.
Basically, if everyone agrees "no gouging of the eyes" and one guy gouges an opponents eyes, everyone has a reason to either force him to make reparations, kick him out of the group and isolate him, or just straight up punish him with force.
Regardless of how strong one country may be, if everyone else isolated them and pointed all their guns at them, that one country couldn't, or shouldn't, be able to proceed very far without being forced to stop.  coughrussiacough

All is fair in love and war, love and war are similar because they are the elements of survival. War: Survival of nations, factions, or self. Love in a way is also survival, because it is for finding your desired mate, fulfilling self needs, and produce your own offspring to continue your legacy/genes. In a way, both things are selfish, and thus you are putting oneself before others, this is where all becomes fair. This is the nature of being human, and it is also inevitable.

Reasons why love "unfairness" does not get prosecuted is because it isn't as serious in compared to warfare. Warfare risks lives, and can determine the death or survival of many people at a time, whereas a person can always have another chance at love. History has treated some people who has committed "love crimes" such as adultery, cheating on spouse, or even being homosexual like criminals, but as our society began to be more open to the concept of love, more freedom brings less restrictions.

Rules of war is great and all, but it will never be perfect. The reason it has improved warfare is due to the mutual agreement of the majority of nations, producing a repercussion toward the violating party that will be harsher compared to the gains achieved through violating the rule in the first place. Chivalry and sportsmanship is not real, what is real is people measuring the gains of a quick (or several) victory against the risk/repercussions of being persecuted by others. 

Take an example of someone who has been convicted of a crime, and knows his only chance of survival would be to murder the single witness that is going to testify against him; if he is convicted of the crime he will be put into the electric chair (in this case). The odds of the person risking murdering the witness would probably out weigh following the rules or being chivalric because that brings a higher chance of survival. 

I am not trying to say anyone can do anything they want (which if you really think about it, you can), but just be prepared to face the consequences when you do.

Rules of war are there so that someone doesn't take things too far. I like to use this example: if country A has 10000 nukes and country B has 10000 nukes, they are equal. But the thing is, if they each have 0 nukes, aren't they still equal? War can't become a race for the most destructive power possible. If both sides "agree" to not try to "outdo" each other, the world is a much safer place. However, if one nation does manage to take over the world unfairly, we can complain all we want about them breaking the rules but unless we can do something about it, there are no rules to war. So pretty much, don't let it get to that stage.
